user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of ws_send_frame:
```c
static ssize_t
ws_send_frame (MHD_socket sock, const char *msg, size_t length)
{
  unsigned char *response;
  unsigned char frame[10];
  unsigned char idx_first_rdata;
  size_t idx_response;
  size_t output;
  MHD_socket isock;
  size_t i;

  frame[0] = (WS_FIN | WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME);
  if (length <= 125)
  {
    frame[1] = length & 0x7F;
    idx_first_rdata = 2;
  }
#if SIZEOF_SIZE_T > 4
  else if (0xFFFF < length)
  {
    frame[1] = 127;
    frame[2] = (unsigned char) ((length >> 56) & 0xFF);
    frame[3] = (unsigned char) ((length >> 48) & 0xFF);
    frame[4] = (unsigned char) ((length >> 40) & 0xFF);
    frame[5] = (unsigned char) ((length >> 32) & 0xFF);
    frame[6] = (unsigned char) ((length >> 24) & 0xFF);
    frame[7] = (unsigned char) ((length >> 16) & 0xFF);
    frame[8] = (unsigned char) ((length >> 8) & 0xFF);
    frame[9] = (unsigned char) (length & 0xFF);
    idx_first_rdata = 10;
  }
#endif /* SIZEOF_SIZE_T > 4 */
  else
  {
    frame[1] = 126;
    frame[2] = (length >> 8) & 0xFF;
    frame[3] = length & 0xFF;
    idx_first_rdata = 4;
  }
  idx_response = 0;
  response = malloc (idx_first_rdata + length + 1);
  if (NULL == response)
  {
    return -1;
  }
  for (i = 0; i < idx_first_rdata; i++)
  {
    response[i] = frame[i];
    idx_response++;
  }
  for (i = 0; i < length; i++)
  {
    response[idx_response] = (unsigned char) msg[i];
    idx_response++;
  }
  response[idx_response] = '\0';
  output = 0;
  if (0 != pthread_mutex_lock (&MUTEX))
    abort ();
  for (i = 0; i < MAX_CLIENTS; i++)
  {
    isock = CLIENT_SOCKS[i];
    if ((isock != MHD_INVALID_SOCKET) && (isock != sock))
    {
      output += send_all (isock, response, idx_response);
    }
  }
  if (0 != pthread_mutex_unlock (&MUTEX))
    abort ();
  free (response);
  return (ssize_t) output;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No calls to any of the <string.h> functions listed in MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) appear in the provided ws_send_frame implementation. Therefore there are no direct string.h usages to inspect for out-of-bounds accesses as required by Rule 21.17. The manual byte copies in this function use explicit index arithmetic with an allocation of response sized to idx_first_rdata + length + 1, the first loop copies idx_first_rdata bytes from frame, the second loop copies length bytes from msg, and a terminating '\0' is written at index idx_first_rdata + length — these indices match the allocated size and do not use any string.h routines. (Note: unrelated concerns such as potential size_t overflow in the allocation expression or correctness of send_all are outside the scope of Rule 21.17 and thus are not flagged here.)
